utterances: So in other words, people were hearing a message that wasn't there.
Yes.
It was not there.
And I would like to ask, you know, K'naan if he's ever experience that with any of his songs.
And I don't mean to cut you off, but we wanted to get an answer.
We just have a few seconds left.
K'NAAN: Yeah, I think that that does often happen.

I think that there's two messages that happen in a song, two informations that the person can receive: one in their ear, which is what you're hearing and the words you're processing, and another in their soul, which is the other information of the music, the spirit of the sound, the moment that you recorded it, the magic that you encapsuled(ph), that you didn't know was there.
That's another information that they're getting.
And so sometimes people respond to, you know, to different things you may not know.

I learned a lot from my audience when I put out a song that, you know, what they think or the conversation that's taking place about my songs sometimes intrigues me because it's not what I meant to talk about.
Donovan, thanks very much.
Good luck.
And, K'naan, thank you so much for being with us today.
K'NAAN: It's a pleasure.
K'naan joined us from your studio in New York, at our bureau there.
Tomorrow, one of the books we missed this year, Tom Ricks' ""The Generals."" Join us for that.
It's the TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
I'm Neal Conan in Washington.
The U.S.
has been trying to give the Sunnis more power.
One part of that strategy is having the military work with former Sunni insurgents and Sunni tribal leaders.
These Sunni groups are called Awakening Councils.
The Awakening Councils have been important in fighting al-Qaida in extremely volatile regions in Iraq, such as Diyala Province.
But these fighters are starting to feel unappreciated, and they're starting to balk at cooperating with the U.S.
Sudarsan Raghavan is the Washington Post's Baghdad bureau chief, and he's spoken to a number of these Awakening Council leaders in and around Baghdad.
He joins us by phone from Amman, Jordan.
Welcome to the program.
Good to be with you.
Thanks for having me.
Now, you went and interviewed some 20 leaders of these Awakening Councils, and what did they tell you?
Well, they did express a great amount of frustration.
And this frustration is on several different levels.
For one reason is that they're being attacked - in fact, according to the U.S.
military, attacks against these Awakening groups have quadrupled since October.
They, you know, they feel that the U.S.
is not giving them enough support in terms of weapons and funding to deal with the al-Qaida in Iraq group.
He is.
And I think the big question is how much President Trump himself gets in on this on Twitter or elsewhere and whether that helps his cause or hurts his cause.
Also with us is Trisha Bailey, a student who served on the committee.
She's with us from the Duke University studios in Durham, North Carolina.
And nice to have you on the program as well.
Thank you as well.
Trisha, you're a student at Duke.
You're also a member of a sorority, Tri Delta.
This report which you helped create talks about a culture of excess and alcohol that's especially linked to Greek life on campus and to athletics.
Is there a culture of excess from your experience?

I think that my experience is not necessarily representative of every student at Duke, but there is a very small percentage of the population -I think here, at least that it's safe to say - does regularly engage in what one would consider excessive behavior, and that's part of what Duke in the past has celebrated as a work hard, play hard culture.
It's just been distorted to be a little bit more extreme.
Mm-hmm.
I think that the majority of students that fall - I'd say about 80 percent of students - don't engage in overly excessive partying behavior and really achieve a healthy balance in their lives.
Larry Moneta, is that - those numbers sound about right to you?
They do.
I think Trisha's accurate in depicting the environment.

I think that a couple of other elements, one is though it's a small number, it's a significant enough number to suggest that that may be the norm, and part of the intent of the initiative is to remind our community and many others that the normative behavior by most of our students is very different from that culture of excess.

Yet one of the other things the report says is that some of the exemplars of this culture of excess are in fact looked up to by a lot of very influential on campus: the top fraternities, the top sororities, and of course student athletes like the lacrosse players.
Well, I think that's true for some.

It's certainly true for enough students that it was of concern to us and one of the reasons why, that we've suggested looking deeply into the environmental conditions, the conditions of privilege that would create the impression that that's the cool.

We've talked a lot in our group about trying to reset the cool, reset the norm so it's more representative of the majority of the students that I think both Trisha and I believe are the majority of our students at Duke.
Trisha, the...
Absolutely.
...the report also speaks about a social environment often disempowering to women, sort of a sterile phrase.
What does it mean in terms of your experience?
Disempowering to women I think often - actually there was a report that came out a few years ago called The Women's Initiative Report...
Mm-hmm.
...and basically it looked at similar things that we are looking at now.
Basically it's a culture regarding women at Duke.

And what it found were two, I think, two very important things, that there is a culture of hooking up, is what we coined, you know, that you don't necessarily have long-term relationships with males here.
That's not always the case, and there's not a real healthy dating scene.
And also something that came out of that was this idea of effortless perfection.

And what effortless perfection means essentially to me, as a Duke female, is that we are expected to be perfect in every way without really trying very hard - that is pretty, intelligent, involved, engaged, and social.
And I think that that can be pretty oppressive for a lot of women here.

It's not to say that every female feels that way or is impacted by that, but our goal with this report was really to affirm the un-perfect Duke students, I think, in many ways, and like Larry said, to reset the norm.

Mm-hmm, and obviously this report a few years ago that Trisha just talked about, Larry Moneta, that report was important in and of itself, yet some of the same problems persist, or at least, you know, persist into this report.
What happened to that report?
Did it have recommendations?
Were they enacted?
Were they enough?
It did, and I have to go back to a sort of an early comment you made about fixing the culture.
Uh-huh.
Now this isn't about fixing the culture.
I mean the culture is long-established and will be established for a long time.
We're talking about trying to make refinements that move us towards the outcomes that we've articulated.
I think the Women's Initiative was an extremely comprehensive approach to understanding the conditions of women at Duke, and I think we've made great progress in that first wave of efforts.
We did several new programs with undergraduate students.
We're proud of a particular program called the Baldwin Scholars.
I think in this latest effort, we've gone beyond the efforts of the Women's Initiative to look at the faculty culture, the curriculum, and many other aspects.
One of the I think exciting opportunities that we had was really to look in a much more interconnected way at the variety of circumstances that contribute to the culture.

So I think this is, you know, this is not something that we started with the Women's Initiative, it's not something that will end with the Campus Culture Initiative, and it's not something that's unique to Duke.
What is unique is our willingness, as evidenced by both of those processes, to step up and figure out what we can do to continue to move to a much better environment for our students.
And not unique to Duke, I wanted to ask you, Larry Moneta, more about that a little bit.
How typical - well, Duke is not typical - but I mean how typical are these kinds of problems that we see at Duke of other campuses around the country?
Yeah, I mean we were interested in that.
I mean I look at that as a trend among young people, not a trend among young people at Duke University.
You work on the show.
Well, I've been at seven different institutions, and I would say that these are exactly the kinds of issues that we struggled with at every one.
Their manifestations are different at each school.
It's a function of what the culture, the rituals, how the privilege is distributed.
In our case we're looking at some of our housing issues because they're unique to our environment.
At other schools it may be the off-campus world.
The - at its core, these are all part of the struggles for young people to achieve adulthood and some of the positive and negative aspects of that.

And at every one of our schools, we're just trying to figure out what are the best opportunities we have to invite students to think differently about their behaviors, think differently about their interactions with people who are like themselves and people who are different from themselves, and move the culture in a very positive way.
Let's get some listeners involved in the conversation.
Our guests are Trisha Bailey, a Duke - a senior at Duke University and a member of the Campus Culture Initiative Committee, and Larry Moneta, the Duke's dean of students.
If you'd like to join us: 800-989-8255, 800-989-TALK.
E-mail is talk@npr.org.
And we'll begin with Emily, Emily calling us from Mount Vernon in Iowa.
Hi, there.
Thank you for taking my call.
Sure.
Well, I go to a very small college in Mount Vernon, Iowa.
I actually transferred from Brown University in Providence, Rhode Island, where I originally went.
And even in this very small town, we have a lot of trouble with drinking.

It's the primary activity because, you know, there's not a whole lot to do in rural Iowa, and so most of the college kids here go out to the bars and get drunk, and we have a lot of alcohol poisoning instances.
There is a lot of issues with rape and such, but it's usually put under the rug because it's a small private college.
And I'm, you know, one of the rare individuals who just does not enjoy drinking.
I don't enjoy getting drunk, and (unintelligible) it's difficult for people like me to have any kind of social life with anyone here that doesn't revolve around drinking.
And it's not even something that, you know, I find myself interested in because of the - you know, it's completely destructive towards, you know, your body and towards other things as well.
Mm-hmm.
But it is basically the center of the social life at the college I go to.

And we've been having storm systems in Iowa, and recently the power went out, and someone drank to the point of getting alcohol poisoning and passed out and hit their head, and there was the whole crisis with that.
And so it's - it is very detrimental to the college life, and it is a very big center of college life in America.
And Trisha...
...and I'm not really sure what can be done about that.
